title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | SB 1.17.19 Part 3 | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | 27-02-2023
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: You do good actions, everything is fine. If you do sinful activity you will suffer.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the topic of discussion, verse 1.17.19 of Srimad Bhagavatam, and outlines three philosophical viewpoints: karma mimamsa, atheistic Sankhya, and atomic philosophy.
segments.transcript: Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Narayanam Namaskritya Naram Chai Vanarottamam Devim Sarasvatim Vyasam Tato Jayam Udi Rayet. In this session, we will continue discussing the 19th verse of the 17th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. This is part 3 of the discussion. In the previous two sessions, we discussed the karma mimamsa philosophy, that is, karma is everything. You do good actions, everything is fine. If you do sinful activity, you will suffer. Then the second kind of philosophers, the atheistic Sankhya philosophers, who analyze material nature as the ultimate cause. Material nature consists of matter. Matter consists of 24 elements, and that they say is everything. Now, the third kind of philosophers, the philosophers headed by Kanada. They accept the combination of atoms as the original cause of the creation. Ultimately, they analyze entire material existence consists of material. Atoms, and that atom is the fundamental particle, and the combination of atoms, there are varieties of objects, persons, things, whatever, everything. Everything ultimately can be broken down only into an atom. So kana, kana means atom in Sanskrit. So this philosopher's name, the sage's name also Kanada because he is explaining everything in terms of atoms, so atomic philosophy.

segments.key_quote: So, the Vedic conception of a material atom is different than the understanding of a material atom as given by today's scientists.
segments.summary: The speaker analyzes the defects in atomic philosophy, contrasting the Vedic concept of an indivisible atom with the modern scientific understanding of atoms consisting of subatomic particles.

segments.summary: The speaker explains the Vedic concept of time, from atomic time to universal time, highlighting the relative nature of time based on different planetary systems and referencing the duration of Brahma's day as described in the Bhagavad Gita.

segments.summary: The speaker continues explaining the calculation of time in relation to Brahma's day and night, contrasting the material world governed by karma with the eternal spiritual world beyond creation and destruction.
